posts.cooked:
Hey everyone!

We have been trying to retread our SDS MK4i swerve modules, however we are finding it impossible to get the screws at the end to thread properly as the tread itself doesn’t seem to be long enough so the screws are going in at an angle which obviously doesn’t work. We have tried following the video posted by SDS on YouTube, however they make it seem so effortless and they don’t seem to have any problem getting the screws in. Are there are any tips and tricks to get them to install easier? Thanks!

We had a similar issue, it got better when we used a straight end hex screwdriver instead of a ball end. We also had to retap some of the holes from accidental crossthreading from some less successful attempts.

posts.name: Ben Thorsgard
posts.cooked: I have had to kind of get the screws to catch the threads diagonally then straighten it out and try to get in without messing it up.  And don’t tighten any of them all the way till you’re done

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
If you want an easier way to attach tread to billet wheels, you should check out this post we made a few days ago about our new method of “sewing” the tread on.

Sewing Wheels: A New Method for Tread Attachment General Forum

link_counts.title: Sewing Wheels: A New Method for Tread Attachment

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: Which tread are you using?  We were having a ton of trouble getting our tread on until we realized that the template we made was for single-ply tread and we were using the thicker 3-ply tread.  Found the correct template dimensions, made a new template, and now it’s a quick and simple process.

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: Check this thread and make sure that you’re using the correct template for the tread that you’re using: Black Neoprene vs Blue Nitrile Tread - #21 by PatrickW

link_counts.title: Black Neoprene vs Blue Nitrile Tread

posts.name: Kara Bakowski
posts.cooked:
Put in the bolts for the ends of the tread FIRST before doing any in the “middle”. It will make it so much easier to get that last one because you will have more length of tread to “stretch”.

What I found helped was using a L allen to do the bolts on the second end, which gives you more control of how you are directing the bolt. Start the bolt with the long side of the L allen at the 12 o’clock position (in red in the first image below), and then as you are turning it down to 6 o’clock, try to “pull” the bolt towards you. What you are trying to do is pull the bolt within the tread so that instead of the bolt being perpendicular to the flat tread and approaching the hole at an angle, the bolt is now going in to the hole straight.

And now for some high quality MS paint drawings:

Start position of allen: image 221×596 1.62 KB

image 221×596 1.62 KB

image 221×596 1.62 KB

Switching to side view, gray bolt outline is “before”, red bolt outline is “after” (dark blue allen wrench shown in the 6 o’clock position)

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
Karibou:

Put in the bolts for the ends of the tread FIRST before doing any in the “middle”.

I’ve found exactly the opposite to be true.  If you put the middles in first, you don’t have to “stretch” the tread so much to get the ends in.

It’s also way easier to put the screws in with a drill compared to any manual tool.  You can get tons of leverage to straighten the screw perpendicular to the hole using a drill.  The trick is to not let a person with no mechanical feel do this.  It needs to be someone who can run the drill with control and stop immediately if there is any resistance indicative of cross-threading.   The drill really saves the stress on the fingers trying to pry the screws perpendicular to the wheel with a hex key while also trying to turn them to go in.  Good manual technique with a hex key tends to go away when your fingers are fatigued working on wheels 3 and 4.

posts.name: Everett33
posts.cooked: The technique we found for the SwerveX wheels is to put a second t-handle allen into the next row and pull the tread while threading in the button heads. This is only good for rows two and three. For the fourth row, do the same but with the t-handle in the hole you are not threading into. For the last hole in the fourth row, we put some 3/16ID spacer stock on the tee handle driving the button head and use the spacers as a handle. One person holds the wheel against their body and tightly pulls the t-handle by the spacer stock with the bolt and tread in tow. A second person then tightens the t-handle, threading the button head into the wheel. Make sure the threads are all chased with a tap before attempting the fourth row.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: what i’ve found works is to screw all but the end first, but loosely, then you kind of have to use some leverage and stretch the tread a bit to line up the last bolts, just be very careful not to cross thread the bolt, cuz its kind of easy to do.
